DoCoFL: Downlink Compression for Cross-Device Federated Learning

Ron Dorfman â€ƒâ€ƒ Shay Vargaftik â€ƒâ€ƒ Yaniv Ben-Itzhak â€ƒâ€ƒ Kfir Y. Levy
Abstract

Many compression techniques have been proposed to reduce the communication overhead of Federated Learning training procedures. However, these are typically designed for compressing model updates, which are expected to decay throughout training. As a result, such methods are inapplicable to downlink (i.e., from the parameter server to clients) compression in the cross-device setting, where heterogeneous clients may appear only once during training and thus must download the model parameters. Accordingly, we propose DoCoFL â€“ a new framework for downlink compression in the cross-device setting. Importantly, DoCoFL can be seamlessly combined with many uplink compression schemes, rendering it suitable for bi-directional compression. Through extensive evaluation, we show that DoCoFL offers significant bi-directional bandwidth reduction while achieving competitive accuracy to that of a baseline without any compression.

Machine Learning, ICML
\declaretheorem

[name=Theorem,numberwithin=section]thm


1 Introduction

In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in federated learning (FL) as a paradigm for large-scale machine learning over decentralized dataÂ (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016a; Kairouz etÂ al., 2021). FL enables organizations and/or devices, collectively termed clients, to jointly build better and more robust models by relying on their collective data and processing power. Importantly, the FL training procedure occurs without exchanging or sharing client-specific data, thus ensuring some degree of privacy and compliance with data access rights and regulationsÂ (e.g., the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) implemented by the European Union in May, 2018). Instead, in each round, clients perform local optimization using their local data and send only model updates to a central coordinator, also known as the parameter server (PS). The PS aggregates these updates and updates the global model, which is then utilized by the clients in subsequent rounds.

One of the main challenges in FL is the communication bottleneck introduced during the distributed training procedure. To illustrate this bottleneck, consider the following example of a real FL deployment presented byÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2022): their training involves a small neural network with 1.31.31.3 million parameters; in each round there are 650065006500 participating clients; and the model is trained over 200020002000 rounds. A simple calculation shows that the total required bandwidth to and from the PS during this training is â‰ˆ61.5absent61.5\approx 61.5 TB. Since modern machine learning models have many millions (or even billions) of parameters and we might haveÂ moreÂ participants,Â FLÂ mayÂ resultÂ inÂ excessiveÂ communicationÂ overhead.

To deal with this overhead, many bandwidth reduction techniques have been proposed. These include taking multiple (rather than a single) local optimization stepsÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), quantization techniquesÂ (Seide etÂ al., 2014; Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Wen etÂ al., 2017; Bernstein etÂ al., 2018a, b; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019; Jin etÂ al., 2020; Shlezinger etÂ al., 2020), low-rank decompositionÂ (Vogels etÂ al., 2019), sketchingÂ (Ivkin etÂ al., 2019; Rothchild etÂ al., 2020), and distributed mean estimationÂ (Lyubarskii & Vershynin, 2010; Suresh etÂ al., 2017; KoneÄná»³ & RichtÃ¡rik, 2018; Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021, 2022; Safaryan etÂ al., 2022). However, as we detail in Â§2, a direct application of these techniques is less suitable for downlink compression, i.e., from the PS to the clients, in the cross-device setup in which new and heterogeneous clients may participate at each round and thus must download the model parameters. This is in contrast to the cross-silo setup in which the PS can compress and send a global update (i.e., clientsâ€™ aggregated update) to all silos.

To the best of our knowledge, only a handful of works consider bi-directional compression, i.e., compression from the clients to the PS and vice versa. These works mainly rely on per-client memory mechanismÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2019; Zheng etÂ al., 2019; Liu etÂ al., 2020; Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020, 2021; Gruntkowska etÂ al., 2022) or require keeping an updated copy of the model on all clients (HorvÃ³th etÂ al., 2022), thus targeting either distributed learning or FL with full or partial but recurring participation (e.g., cross-silo FL). Such solutions are less suitable for large-scale cross-device FL, where a client may appear only a handful of times, or even just once, during the entire training procedure.

It is important to stress that the significance of bi-directional bandwidth reduction for cross-device FL goes far beyond cost reduction, energy efficiency, and carbon footprint considerations. In fact, inclusion, fairness, and bias are at the very heart of cross-device FL as, according to recent sourcesÂ (Sumra, 2020; Howdle, 2022), the price of a wireless connection and its quality admits differences of orders of magnitude among countries. This may prevent large populations from contributing to cross-device FL training due to costly and unstable connectivity, resulting in biased and less accurate models.

Accordingly, in this work we introduce DoCoFL, a novel downlink compression framework specifically designed for cross-device FL. Importantly, it operates independently of many uplink compression techniques, making it suitable for bi-directional compression in cross-device setups.

The primary challenge addressed by DoCoFL is that clients must download model parameters (i.e., weights) instead of model updates. Unlike updates, which are proportional to gradients and thus their norm is expected to decrease during training, the model parameters do not decay, rendering low-bit compression methods undesirable. As a result, and since clients can only download the updated model weights during their designated participation round, this can lead to a network bottleneck for low-resourced clients.

To address this bottleneck, DoCoFL decomposes the download burden by utilizing previous models, referred to as anchors, which clients can download prior to their participation round. Then, at the designated participation round, clients only need to download the correction, i.e., the difference between the updated model and the anchor. As the correction is proportionate to the sum of previous updates, it is expected to decay, allowing for the use of low-bit compression methods. To ensure the correction term, PS memory footprint, and PS computational overhead remain manageable, the available anchors are updated periodically. This approach reduces the amount of bandwidth required by the clients online (i.e., at their participation round). To reduce the overall downlink bandwidth usage, we further develop and utilize an efficient anchor compression technique with an appealing bandwidth-accuracy tradeoff.

Contributions.

We summarize our contributions below,

  • â€¢

    We propose a new framework (DoCoFL) that both enlarges the time window during which clients can obtain the model parameters and reduces the total downlink bandwidth requirements for cross-device FL.

  • â€¢

    We show that DoCoFL provably converges to a stationary point when not compressing anchors and give an asymptotic convergence rate.

  • â€¢

    We design a new compression technique with strong empirical results, which DoCoFL uses for anchor compression and can be of independent interest. We provide the theoretical intuition and empirical evidence for why DoCoFL with anchor compression works.

Finally, we show over image classification and language processing tasks that DoCoFL consistently achieves model accuracy that is competitive with an uncompressed baseline, namely, FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) while reducing bandwidth usage in both directions by order of magnitude.

2 Background and Related Work

In this section, we overview mostly related work and detail the challenges in designing a bi-directional bandwidth reduction framework for cross-device FL.

2.1 Uplink vs. Downlink Compression

In the context of FL, uplink (i.e., client to PS) and downlink (i.e., PS to client) compression are inherently different and should not be treated in the same manner. In particular, many recent uplink compression solutions (e.g., KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016b); Alistarh etÂ al. (2017)) partially rely on two properties to obtain their effectiveness:

Averaging. A fundamental property arises when many clients send their compressed gradients for averaging at the PS. If the clientsâ€™ estimates are independent and unbiased, the error in estimating their mean by calculating their estimationsâ€™ mean is decreasing linearly with respect to the number of clients. Thus, having more clients in each round allows for more aggressive and more accurate compression.

Error Decay. Essentially, unbiased compression of updates results in an increased variance in their estimation. This increase can be compensated by decreasing the learning rate. Moreover, the effect of update compression is expected to diminish since the expected update decays as the training process approaches a stationary point. This is not the case when compression model parameters.

For downlink compression, we immediately lose the averaging property since, by design, there is only one source with whom the clients communicate, namely, the PS. Regarding the error decay property, we must further distinguish between different FL setups as described next.

2.2 Cross-silo vs. Cross-device FL

FL can be divided into two types based on the nature of the participating clients (Kairouz etÂ al. (2021), Table 1).

Silos. In cross-silo FL, the clients are typically assumed to be active throughout the training procedure and with sufficient compute and network resources. Silos are typically associated with entities such as hospitals that jointly train a model for better diagnosis and treatmentÂ (Ng etÂ al., 2021) or banks that jointly build better models for fraud and anomalous activity detectionÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019).

Indeed, silos allow for the design of efficient compression techniques that rely on client persistency and per-client memory mechanisms that are used for, e.g., compressing gradient differences, employing error feedback, and learning control variatesÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2018; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2021; RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al., 2021). While most of these techniques consider only uplink compression, some recent works target bi-directional compression by utilizing the same property of using per-client memory and relying on repeated client participationÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2019; Liu etÂ al., 2020; Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020, 2021; Gruntkowska etÂ al., 2022).

Devices. In cross-device FL, clients are typically assumed to be heterogeneous and not persistent to the extent that a client often participates in a single out of many thousands of training rounds. Also, in this setup, clients may often admit compute and network constraints. Devices are usually associated with entities such as laptops, smartphones, smartwatches, tablets, and IoT devices. A typical example of a cross-device FL application is keyboard completion for android devicesÂ (McMahan & Ramage, 2017).

Unlike in silos with full or partial but repeated participation, compression techniques for devices that appear only once or a handful of times cannot rely on having some earlier state for or on that device. This renders methods that rely on per-client memory or learned control variates less suitable for such cross-device FL setups. Indeed, recent gradient compression techniques can be readily used for bi-directional compression in the cross-silo setup or only uplink compression in both setupsÂ (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016b; Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Suresh etÂ al., 2017; Ramezani-Kebrya etÂ al., 2021; Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021, 2022; Safaryan etÂ al., 2022).

2.3 Putting It All Together

As summarized in Table 1, differences in the clientsâ€™ nature and the compression direction (i.e., uplink vs. downlink) significantly affect the efficiency of bandwidth reduction techniques. In the considered setups, downlink compression is more challenging than uplink compression due to the lack of averaging and received considerably less attention in the literature. Moreover, for the cross-device setup, the problem is more acute due to not having error decay as well.

3 DoCoFL

In this section, we present DoCoFL. We start with describing our design goals, which are derived from the challenges outlined in the previous section, followed by a formal definition of the federated optimization problem. Then, in Â§3.1, we give intuition and introduce our framework. In Â§3.2, we detail about an important element of DoCoFL, namely, the client selection process employed by the PS. Finally, we provide a theoretical convergence result in Â§3.3.

Design Goals. Motivated by the discussion in the previous section, we aim at achieving two goals to deal with the low bandwidth and slow and unstable connectivity conditions that edge devices may experience:

  1. 1.

    Enlarging the time window during which a client can download the model weights from the PS.

  2. 2.

    Reducing the bandwidth requirements in the downlink direction.

Achieving both these goals will enable more heterogeneous clients to participate in the training process, which in turn may reduce bias and improve fairness111By fairness, we refer to the situation where clients in regions with limited, unstable, and costly connectivity are keen to participate in the training procedure..

Preliminaries. We use âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…\lVert\cdot\rVert to denote the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} norm and for every nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in{\mathbb{N}}, [n]â‰”{1,â€¦,n}â‰”delimited-[]ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘›\left[n\right]\coloneqq\left\{1,\ldots,n\right\}. Let Nğ‘N be the number of clients participating in the federated training procedure. Each client iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in\left[N\right] is associated with a local loss function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, and our goal is to minimize the loss with respect to all clients, i.e., to solve

minwâˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(w)â‰”1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(w).â‰”subscriptğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¤1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤\min_{w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}}{f(w)\coloneqq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{f_{i}(w)}}\;. (1)

Unlike in standard distributed optimization or cross-silo FL with full or partial but repeated participation, in cross-device FL, only a subset of Sğ‘†S clients participate in each optimization round and typically Sâ‰ªNmuch-less-thanğ‘†ğ‘S\ll N (e.g., Sğ‘†S in the hundreds/thousands and Nğ‘N in many millions). Thus, clients are not expected to repeatedly participate in the optimization.

Since FL mostly considers non-convex optimization (e.g., neural networks), and global loss minimization of such models is generally intractable, we focus on finding an approximate stationary point, i.e., a point wğ‘¤w for which the expected gradient norm ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)âˆ¥ğ”¼delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¤\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(w)\rVert tends to zero.

For the purpose of formal analysis, we make a few standard assumptions, namely, that fğ‘“f is bounded from below by fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}, the local functions {fi}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\left\{f_{i}\right\} are Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth, i.e., âˆ¥âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(u)âˆ¥â‰¤Î²â€‹âˆ¥wâˆ’uâˆ¥,âˆ€w,uâˆˆâ„dformulae-sequencedelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ›½delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¤ğ‘¢for-allğ‘¤ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f_{i}(u)\rVert\leq\beta\lVert w-u\rVert,\forall w,u\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, and the access to each local function is done via a stochastic gradient oracle, i.e.,

Assumption 3.1.

For any wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, client iğ‘–i computes an unbiased gradient estimator giâ€‹(w)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘¤g^{i}(w) with a variance that is upper bounded by Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, i.e.,

ğ”¼â€‹[giâ€‹(w)]=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w),ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥giâ€‹(w)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w)âˆ¥2â‰¤Ïƒ2.formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘¤âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘¤âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤2superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}[g^{i}(w)]=\nabla f_{i}(w),\enskip\mathbb{E}\lVert g^{i}(w)-\nabla f_{i}(w)\rVert^{2}\!\leq\!\sigma^{2}\;. (2)

Additionally, we assume that the dissimilarity of the local gradients is bounded (i.e., limited client data heterogeneity).

Assumption 3.2.

There exist constants G,Bâˆˆâ„+ğºğµsubscriptâ„G,B\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+} such that for every wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}:

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ¥âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w)âˆ¥2â‰¤G2+B2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)âˆ¥2.1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤2superscriptğº2superscriptğµ2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¤2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)\rVert^{2}}\leq G^{2}+B^{2}\lVert\nabla f(w)\rVert^{2}\;. (3)

While some works consider milderÂ (Khaled & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020; Haddadpour etÂ al., 2021) or noÂ (Gorbunov etÂ al., 2021) assumptions on client heterogeneity in some settings (e.g., exact gradients and/or full participation), this assumption is standard in heterogeneous federated learningÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Wang etÂ al., 2020; Reddi etÂ al., 2021).

3.1 Overview

A naive approach to reduce bandwidth in the downlink direction is to apply some compression to the model weights and have all participating clients download the compressed weights. That is, in each round tğ‘¡t, the participating clients ğ’®tâŠ†[N]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{S}_{t}\subseteq\left[N\right] obtain a compressed version of the model weights w^t=ğ’wâ€‹(wt)subscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\hat{w}_{t}=\mathcal{C}_{w}(w_{t}), for some compression operator ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w}. The clients can then compute an unbiased gradient estimator at w^tsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\hat{w}_{t} and send it back to the PS for aggregation.

While this method is fairly simple, it has inherent disadvantages with respect to our goals. First, there is no enlarged time window during which clients can download the compressed model weights, as they can only do so at their participation round. Second, unlike with gradient compression, convergence in this setting can be guaranteed only to a proximity that is proportional to the compression error, rendering standard low-bit compression schemes unusable. Indeed, this is the case even for strongly convex functions, as shown byÂ Chraibi etÂ al. (2019) and reinforced by our counter-example in AppendixÂ A.

To tackle these challenges, our approach relies on the following relation: for any Ï„â‰¥0ğœ0\tau\geq 0, we can decompose wtsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t} into two ingredients: Anchor and Correction. Formally,

wt=wtâˆ’Ï„âŸ(i) Anchor+wtâˆ’wtâˆ’Ï„âŸ(ii) Correction.subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptâŸsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ(i) AnchorsubscriptâŸsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ(ii) Correction\quad w_{t}=\underbrace{w_{t-\tau}}_{\textit{(i) Anchor}}+\underbrace{w_{t}-w_{t-\tau}}_{\textit{(ii) Correction}}\;.

This implies that:

  • (i)

    If a client is notified at round tâˆ’Ï„ğ‘¡ğœt-\tau about its upcoming participation at round tğ‘¡t, it can start downloading the anchor, that is, wtâˆ’Ï„subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœw_{t-\tau}, ahead of its participation round,222The client can start downloading wtâˆ’Ï„â€²subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptğœâ€²w_{t-\tau^{\prime}} at round tâˆ’Ï„â€²ğ‘¡superscriptğœâ€²t-\tau^{\prime} for some Ï„â€²â‰¤Ï„superscriptğœâ€²ğœ\tau^{\prime}\leq\tau, as long as the download is complete before round tğ‘¡t.

  • (ii)

    and thus, at round tğ‘¡t, the client only needs to download the correction, that is, wtâˆ’wtâˆ’Ï„subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœw_{t}-w_{t-\tau}.

Yet, merely relying on this relation is not sufficient to achieve our goals; additionally, we seek to compress both (i) and (ii). However, these terms are inherently different and therefore, should not be treated in the same manner. Essentially, the client has more time to download (i), which is the main ingredient that forms the model weights. Introducing a large error in this term may prevent the model from converging. Conversely, (ii) must be downloaded at the participation round of the client, but it is just the sum of Ï„ğœ\tau recent gradients.

For (i), we develop a new compression technique (seeÂ Â§4), that achieves a better accuracy-bandwidth tradeoff than gradient compression techniques at the cost of higher complexity; we amortize its complexity over several rounds. Using this technique with only several bits per coordinate (e.g., 444) results in a negligible error. For (ii), we use standard gradient compression techniques with as low as 0.50.50.5 bit per coordinate. Since (ii) is only a sum of Ï„ğœ\tau recent gradients, this error is expected to decay as training progresses.

Overall, we achieve both goals as (1) the download time window is enlarged, with only a small bandwidth fraction that must be used online; and (2) the total downlink bandwidth usage is reduced by up to an order of magnitude compared to existing solutions and without degrading model accuracy.

In FigureÂ 1, we show a timeline that illustrates the training procedure of DoCoFL, as we now formally detail on the role of the PS and the clients in our framework.

Parameter Server. As detailed in AlgorithmÂ 1, our PS executes three separate processes throughout the training procedure. First, it performs â€˜anchor deploymentâ€™ â€“ once in every Kğ¾K rounds, it compresses the model weights and stores the compressed weights in a queue Qğ‘„Q of length ğ’±ğ’±{\mathcal{V}}. Second, the PS employs a client participation process, which we elaborate on in Â§3.2; this process determines which clients will participate in a given round. Finally, in each round, the PS obtains the local model updates (i.e., gradients) from the clients participating in that round, computes their average, and updates the model weights.

Client. Consider a client that is chosen by the PS at some round sğ‘ s to participate in some future round tğ‘¡t. This means that in round sâ‰¤tğ‘ ğ‘¡s\leq t, the client is notified about its upcoming participation. It can then start downloading the latest anchor stored by the PS; note that the client has a time window of length tâˆ’sğ‘¡ğ‘ t-s rounds to download the compressed anchor. At its participation round tğ‘¡t, the client obtains the compressed correction from the PS, i.e., the compressed difference between the updated model and the compressed anchor obtained earlier, to construct an unbiased estimate of the updated model weights.333The client obtains the (unbiasedly) compressed difference between wtsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t} and the compressed anchor rather than the exact anchor. Thus, the model estimate is unbiased, even if the compressor ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is biased. A similar mechanism was used by HorvÃ¡th & RichtÃ¡rik (2020) for gradient compression, i.e., â€˜induced compressorâ€™.Â It then locally computes a stochastic gradient, compresses it, and sends the compressed gradient to the PS; see AlgorithmÂ 2.

3.2 Client Participation Process

An important element in DoCoFL is the client participation process ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}. For a round number tğ‘¡t, it returns a subset of clients ğ’®tâŠ†[N]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{S}_{t}\subseteq\left[N\right] of size Sğ‘†S to participate in that round. Crucially, in DoCoFL, clients can be notified about their participation prior to their actual participation round.

This discrepancy between the notification and the participation rounds gives DoCoFL the desired versatility that opens the door for more clients to participate in the optimization process. While current frameworks follow a selection process that notifies a client about its participation just before it takes place, it is possible to consider useful selection/notification processes where some clients (e.g., with weaker connectivity) are notified earlier than others.

Another point to consider is the bias-utility tradeoff, where some choices of ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} can allow more clients to participate but may introduce bias in the participation rounds of clients with an untractable effect on the optimization process. Instead, we focus on processes that preserve the property where at each round, the PS can obtain an unbiased estimate of the gradient, which means that we require ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} to satisfy the following property: all clients have the same probability of participating in any given round tğ‘¡t, i.e., â„™â€‹(iâˆˆğ’«â€‹(t))=S/Nâ„™ğ‘–ğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ‘\mathbb{P}(i\in\mathcal{P}(t))=S/N. Surprisingly, such a restriction allows for a wide range of useful selection policies.

For example, consider a simple scenario where the PS has predetermined time windows Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s} and Twsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¤T_{w} that it associates with â€œstrongly connectedâ€ and â€œweakly connectedâ€ devices, respectively. Then, at each round tğ‘¡t, the PS randomly selects clients but assigns their participation rounds to t+Tsğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ t+T_{s} or t+Twğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¤t+T_{w} according to their strength. Observe that this simple, yet very useful scenario satisfies the property we seek after Twsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¤T_{w} rounds (the first Twsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¤T_{w} rounds may take longer since, during these initial rounds, the weakly connected clients cannot be notified enough rounds prior to their participation).

3.3 Theoretical Guarantee

The primary challenge in analyzing downlink compression schemes for cross-device FL is that, even when using an unbiased compression method, for which ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’wâ€‹(w)]=wğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘¤\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{C}_{w}(w)]=w, the resulting gradient estimate âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’wâ€‹(w))âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ’ğ‘¤ğ‘¤\nabla f(\mathcal{C}_{w}(w)) may be biased. This is because, in general, the gradient is not a linear mapping. As mentioned, the resulting bias can hinder convergence; in AppendixÂ A we show that gradient descent with weights compression may not reach the optimal solution even for strongly convex functions.

Accordingly, we show that DoCoFL converges to a stationary point when ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is the identity mapping, i.e., ğ’wâ€‹(w)=w,âˆ€wâˆˆâ„dformulae-sequencesubscriptğ’ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘¤for-allğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}_{w}(w)=w,\forall w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} â€“ a setup that achieves our first goal (i.e., enlarged time window). As our analysis suggests, this identity assumption enables us to effectively bound the gradient bias resulting from the compression. For simplicity, we also assume no uplink compression (i.e., ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g} is also identity), although including it in our analysis is straightforward for unbiased ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g}444Unbiasedness in the uplink direction is highly desired since (together with independence) it ensures linearly decaying mean estimation error with respect to the number of clients. For biased ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g}, in light of existing results on biased compressors (Beznosikov etÂ al., 2020), it may be the case that for some biased compressors the theoretical guarantee, with additional challenges, holds., and we do incorporate it in our experiments.

Following this result, and the result of Chraibi etÂ al. (2019) in the convex case, in AppendixÂ B we give a theoretical intuition and empirical evidence for why DoCoFL works well in setups of interest, when ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is not the identity function â€“ achieving our second goal (i.e., total bandwidth reduction).

Before we state our convergence result, we require an additional standard assumption about the correction compression operator ğ’csubscriptğ’ğ‘\mathcal{C}_{c}, namely, that it has a bounded Normalized Mean-Squared-Error (NMSE)Â (Philippenko & Dieuleveut, 2020; RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al., 2021; Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021).

Assumption 3.3.

There exists an Ï‰âˆˆâ„+ğœ”subscriptâ„\omega\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+} such that

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ¥ğ’câ€‹(w)âˆ’wâˆ¥2]â‰¤Ï‰2â€‹âˆ¥wâˆ¥2,âˆ€wâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ’ğ‘ğ‘¤ğ‘¤2superscriptğœ”2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¤2for-allğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{E}\left[\lVert\mathcal{C}_{c}(w)-w\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\omega^{2}\lVert w\rVert^{2},\quad\forall w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\;. (4)

We now give a convergence result for DoCoFL, namely, TheoremÂ 3.4. Its full proof is deferred to AppendixÂ C; here, we discuss the result and give a proof sketch.

Theorem 3.4.

Let M=fâ€‹(w0)âˆ’fâˆ—,Ïƒ~2=Ïƒ2+4â€‹(1âˆ’SN)â€‹G2formulae-sequenceğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤0superscriptğ‘“superscript~ğœ2superscriptğœ241ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğº2M\!=\!f(w_{0}){-}f^{*},\tilde{\sigma}^{2}\!=\!\sigma^{2}{+}4\left(1{-}\frac{S}{N}\right)G^{2}, and Î³=1+(1âˆ’SN)â€‹B2Sğ›¾11ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğµ2ğ‘†\gamma=1+\left(1{-}\frac{S}{N}\right)\frac{B^{2}}{S}. Then, DoCoFL with ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} and ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g} as identity mappings (and appropriate Î·ğœ‚\eta) guarantees

ğ”¼[1Tâˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1âˆ¥âˆ‡f(wt)âˆ¥2]âˆˆğ’ª(Mâ€‹Î²â€‹Ïƒ~2Tâ€‹S+\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\lVert\nabla f(w_{t})\rVert^{2}}\right]\in\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{M\beta\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{TS}}\right.+
(M2â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹Ïƒ~2)1/3T2/3â€‹S1/3+Î³â€‹Mâ€‹Î²â€‹(Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±+1)T).\displaystyle\left.\frac{(M^{2}\beta^{2}\omega^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\tilde{\sigma}^{2})^{1/3}}{T^{2/3}S^{1/3}}+\frac{\gamma M\beta(\omega K{\mathcal{V}}+1)}{T}\right).

The convergence rate in TheoremÂ 3.4 consists of three terms:

  • â€¢

    The first term Mâ€‹Î²â€‹Ïƒ~2Tâ€‹Sğ‘€ğ›½superscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†\sqrt{\frac{M\beta\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{TS}} is a slow statistical term that depends only on the noise level Ïƒ~2superscript~ğœ2\tilde{\sigma}^{2} (and the objectiveâ€™s properties); importantly, it is independent of DoCoFLâ€™s hyperparameters, K,ğ’±ğ¾ğ’±K,{\mathcal{V}}, and Ï‰ğœ”\omega.

  • â€¢

    The last term Î³â€‹Mâ€‹Î²â€‹(Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±+1)Tğ›¾ğ‘€ğ›½ğœ”ğ¾ğ’±1ğ‘‡\frac{\gamma M\beta(\omega K{\mathcal{V}}+1)}{T} is a fast deterministic term. When Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±âˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğœ”ğ¾ğ’±ğ’ª1\omega K{\mathcal{V}}\in\mathcal{O}(1) it decreases proportionally to 1/T1ğ‘‡1/T, and otherwise, it is proportional to Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±/Tğœ”ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘‡\omega K{\mathcal{V}}/T.

  • â€¢

    The middle term (M2â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹Ïƒ~2)1/3T2/3â€‹S1/3superscriptsuperscriptğ‘€2superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2ğ¾ğ’±superscript~ğœ213superscriptğ‘‡23superscriptğ‘†13\frac{(M^{2}\beta^{2}\omega^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\tilde{\sigma}^{2})^{1/3}}{T^{2/3}S^{1/3}} is a moderate term that depends on both noise level and DoCoFLâ€™s hyperparameters through the multiplication Ï‰2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹Ïƒ~2superscriptğœ”2ğ¾ğ’±superscript~ğœ2\omega^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\tilde{\sigma}^{2}; it is proportionate to (T2/3â€‹S1/3)âˆ’1superscriptsuperscriptğ‘‡23superscriptğ‘†131(T^{2/3}S^{1/3})^{-1}.

We next derive observations from TheoremÂ 3.4. Henceforth, we omit from ğ’ªâ€‹(â‹…)ğ’ªâ‹…\mathcal{O}(\cdot) the dependence on M,Î²ğ‘€ğ›½M,\beta, and Î³ğ›¾\gamma.

Corollary 3.5.

When ğ’csubscriptğ’ğ‘\mathcal{C}_{c} is the identity mapping, i.e., Ï‰=0ğœ”0\omega{=}0, clients obtain the exact model, and thus our method is equivalent to FedAvg. Indeed, we get the same asymptotic rate as FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019), namely, ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ~2/Tâ€‹S+1/T)ğ’ªsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}/TS}+1/T).

Corollary 3.6.

Suppose Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±âˆˆÎ˜â€‹(1)ğœ”ğ¾ğ’±Î˜1\omega K{\mathcal{V}}\in\Theta(1). In that case, we get the following asymptotic rate:

ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ~2Tâ€‹S+(Ï‰â€‹Ïƒ~2)1/3T2/3â€‹S1/3+1T).ğ’ªsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†superscriptğœ”superscript~ğœ213superscriptğ‘‡23superscriptğ‘†131ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{TS}}+\frac{(\omega\tilde{\sigma}^{2})^{1/3}}{T^{2/3}S^{1/3}}+\frac{1}{T}\right)\;.

Compared to CorollaryÂ 3.5, we note that the middle term is the additional cost incurred for utilizing compression. Importantly, it decreases when we improve the correction compression, i.e., reduce Ï‰ğœ”\omega.

Corollary 3.7.

Consider Ï‰=Î˜â€‹(1)ğœ”Î˜1\omega\!=\!\Theta(1). If Kâ€‹ğ’±âˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ~2â€‹T/S)ğ¾ğ’±ğ’ªsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†K{\mathcal{V}}\in\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}T/S}), the slow term dominates the rate, which is ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ~2/Tâ€‹S)ğ’ªsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}/TS}); that is, we can set Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ¾ğ’±K{\mathcal{V}} as large as ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ~2â€‹T/S)ğ’ªsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}T/S}) and still get, similarly to FedAvg, a speed-up with Sğ‘†S, the number of participating clients per-round.

Proof Sketch. Denote: âˆ‡tâ‰”âˆ‡fâ€‹(wt)â‰”subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\nabla_{t}\!\coloneqq\!\nabla f(w_{t}) and âˆ‡^tâ‰”ğ”¼â€‹[g^t]â‰”subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡\hat{\nabla}_{t}\!\coloneqq\!\mathbb{E}[\hat{g}_{t}]. By the update rule, the smoothness of the objective and standard arguments, we obtain that

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})]\leq âˆ’Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²â€‹Î·22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle-\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}
+Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡^tâˆ’âˆ‡tâˆ¥2.ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2\displaystyle+\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nabla}_{t}-\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}\;. (5)

Using the smoothness of fğ‘“f, we can bound the last term in the right-hand side, corresponding to the gradient bias, by the clientsâ€™ average compression error:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡^tâˆ’âˆ‡tâˆ¥2â‰¤Î²2â‹…ğ”¼â€‹[1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tâˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2].ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2â‹…superscriptğ›½2ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nabla}_{t}-\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}\leq\beta^{2}\cdot\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}{\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\right]\;. (6)

Additionally, in LemmaÂ C.1, we derive the following bound on the second moment of the stochastic aggregated gradient:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2â‰¤Ïƒ~2S+4â€‹Î³â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+2â€‹Î²2Sâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tâˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2.ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2superscript~ğœ2ğ‘†4ğ›¾ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡22superscriptğ›½2ğ‘†ğ”¼subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}\!\leq\!\frac{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{S}{+}4\gamma\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}{+}\frac{2\beta^{2}}{S}\mathbb{E}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}{\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}. (7)

Plugging these bounds back to Eq.Â (3.3), we obtain:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})]\leq (âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²â€‹Î·2â€‹Ïƒ~22â€‹Sğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2superscript~ğœ22ğ‘†\displaystyle\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}{+}2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}{+}\frac{\beta\eta^{2}\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{2S}
+(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tâˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2].superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle+\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}{+}\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}{\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\right].\vspace{-2mm} (8)

Recall that each client constructs the current model estimate by summing an anchor and a compressed correction, i.e., w^ti=yti+ğ’câ€‹(wtâˆ’yti)superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{w}_{t}^{i}=y_{t}^{i}+\mathcal{C}_{c}(w_{t}-y_{t}^{i}), where ytisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–y_{t}^{i} (i.e., the anchor) is some model from up to Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ¾ğ’±K{\mathcal{V}} rounds ago; for simplicity, assume that all clients obtain the oldest anchor, i.e., yti=wtâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±y_{t}^{i}=w_{t-K{\mathcal{V}}}. Therefore, using AssumptionÂ 3.3, we can bound the compression error by the difference between the current model and the obtained anchor, which is proportional to the sum of the last few (aggregated) gradients:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2â‰¤Ï‰2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥wtâˆ’ytiâˆ¥2=Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1g^kâˆ¥2.ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ”2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–2superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘¡1subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}{-}w_{t}\rVert^{2}\leq\omega^{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert w_{t}-y_{t}^{i}\rVert^{2}=\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\hat{g}_{k}}\bigg{\rVert}^{2}.

Denote the client compression error by etiâ‰”ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2â‰”superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2e_{t}^{i}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}. Decomposing each gradient into bias and variance as g^k=âˆ‡^k+Î¾^ksubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘˜subscript^ğœ‰ğ‘˜\hat{g}_{k}=\hat{\nabla}_{k}+\hat{\xi}_{k}, where ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾^k]=0ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript^ğœ‰ğ‘˜0\mathbb{E}[\hat{\xi}_{k}]=0, we get:

etisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle e_{t}^{i} â‰¤2Ï‰2Î·2ğ”¼âˆ¥âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1âˆ‡^kâˆ¥2+2Ï‰2Î·2ğ”¼âˆ¥âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1Î¾^kâˆ¥2\displaystyle\leq 2\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\hat{\nabla}_{k}}\bigg{\rVert}^{2}+2\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\rVert}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\hat{\xi}_{k}}\bigg{\rVert}^{2}
â‰¤2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡^kâˆ¥2+2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥Î¾^kâˆ¥2,absent2superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¾ğ’±superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘¡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘˜22superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘¡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğœ‰ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\leq 2\omega^{2}\eta^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nabla}_{k}\rVert^{2}}{+}2\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\xi}_{k}\rVert^{2}},

where we used the orthogonality of the noises, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾^kâŠ¤â€‹Î¾^â„“]=0ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript^ğœ‰ğ‘˜topsubscript^ğœ‰â„“0\mathbb{E}[\hat{\xi}_{k}^{\top}\hat{\xi}_{\ell}]=0 for kâ‰ â„“ğ‘˜â„“k\neq\ell. Plugging-in Î¾^k=g^kâˆ’âˆ‡^ksubscript^ğœ‰ğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘˜\hat{\xi}_{k}=\hat{g}_{k}-\hat{\nabla}_{k}, we obtain:

etisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle e_{t}^{i} â‰¤6â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡^kâˆ¥2+4â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹âˆ‘k=tâˆ’Kâ€‹ğ’±tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^kâˆ¥2.absent6superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¾ğ’±superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘¡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘˜24superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ’±ğ‘¡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\!\leq\!6\omega^{2}\eta^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nabla}_{k}\rVert^{2}}{+}4\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\sum_{k=t-K{\mathcal{V}}}^{t-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{k}\rVert^{2}}.

Using Eq.Â (6) and (7) to bound ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡^kâˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘˜2\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nabla}_{k}\rVert^{2} and ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^kâˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜2\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{k}\rVert^{2}, respectively, we get a recursive relation as the client compression error at round tğ‘¡t depends on all prior errors. This is due to error accumulation from computing the aggregated gradients at inaccurate iterates. LemmaÂ C.2 provides a (non-recursive) bound on the compression error at round tğ‘¡t. Plugging this bound back to Eq.â€‚(3.3), summing over t=0,â€¦,Tâˆ’1ğ‘¡0â€¦ğ‘‡1t=0,\ldots,T-1, and using some algebra, we get:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wT)âˆ’fâ€‹(w0)]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤0absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{T})-f(w_{0})]\leq âˆ’Î·4â€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2ğœ‚4superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2\displaystyle-\frac{\eta}{4}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}}
+(Î²â€‹Î·22+12â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹Î·3)â€‹Tâ€‹Ïƒ~2S.ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2212superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2ğ¾ğ’±superscriptğœ‚3ğ‘‡superscript~ğœ2ğ‘†\displaystyle+\left(\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}+12\beta^{2}\omega^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\eta^{3}\right)\frac{T\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{S}\;.

Rearranging terms and tuning Î·ğœ‚\eta concludes the proof. â€‹â–¡â–¡\hbox{}\nobreak\hfill\square

It is important to note that our framework may also introduce some opportunities for system-wise improvements that are not captured by standard analysis. For example, with a larger pool of clients that are able to participate in a training procedure, it may be easier and faster to reach the desired threshold of participants in each round. Also, it may offer access to more data overall with a different resulting model. How to capture and model such potential benefits in a way that is consistent with and useful in real deployments? Indeed, this is an interesting and significant challenge for future work that may yield new FL policies.

4 Anchor Compression

Compressing the anchors is an essential building block of DoCoFL for reducing the total downlink bandwidth. While many compression techniques exist, most techniques were designed for gradient compression. Although we can use many such methods in our framework, it is less desirable to use a gradient compression scheme for anchor compression since the compression error of the anchor has a larger impact on the resulting model accuracy than the correction error; recall that the model weights, unlike the correction, do not decay throughout training. Accordingly, we designed a compression technique for that purpose.

We first observe that this technique is considerably lessÂ restricted on the PS side (i.e., compression) than on the clientâ€™s side (i.e., decompression). On the PS side, we typically have more resources and time (a new anchor is deployed only every Kğ¾K rounds) to employ more complex calculations, where at the client side we seek speed and lighter computations.

Consequently, we devised a compression method called Entropy-Constrained Uniform Quantization (ECUQ). The main idea behind this approach is to approximate Entropy-Constrained Quantization (ECQ), which is an optimal scheme among a large family of quantization techniquesÂ (Chou etÂ al., 1989). Intuitively, given some vector, ECQ finds the best quantization values (i.e., those that minimize the mean squared error) such that after quantization and entropy encoding (e.g., Huffman coding,Â Huffman (1952)) of the resulting quantized vector, a given budget constraint is respected. However, this approach is slow, complex, and unstable (sensitive to hyperparameters), which renders it unsuitable for online compression of large vectors.

As we detail in AppendixÂ D, ECUQ employs a double binary search to efficiently find the maximal number of uniformly spaced quantization values (between the minimal and maximal values of the input vector), such that after quantization, the entropy of the vector would be within a small threshold from a given bandwidth constraint. Since computing the entropy of a vector does not require to actually encode it, the double binary search is executed fast, and only after finding these quantization values, we encode the vector.

In AppendixÂ D, we compare ECUQ, ECQ and a technique based on K-Means clustering (ECK-Means), which also approximates ECQ (see FigureÂ 6); our results indicate that ECUQ is always better than ECK-Means and competitive with ECQ while being orders of magnitude faster.

We also compare ECUQ with four recent gradient compression techniques: (1) Hadamard followed by stochastic quantization (SQ)Â (Suresh etÂ al., 2017); (2) Kashinâ€™s representation followed by SQÂ (Lyubarskii & Vershynin, 2010; Safaryan etÂ al., 2022); (3) QSGD followed by Elias Gamma encodingÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017); and (4) EDENÂ (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2022). We test these in three different scenarios: (1) Model parameters of a convolutional neural network (CNN) withÂ â‰ˆ11absent11\approx{11}M parameters; (2) Model parameters of an LSTM network withÂ â‰ˆ8absent8\approx{8}M parameters; and (3) Vectors from a LogNormal(0,1)01(0,1) distribution with 111M entries.Â We repeat each experiment ten times and report the mean.

As shown in FigureÂ 2, ECUQ consistently offers the best NMSE, which is by up to an order of magnitude better than that of the second best. We also find that ECUQ is sufficiently fast to be used by the PS every several rounds (a typical cross-device FL round may take minutes to hours).

While our comparison here focuses on quantization-based methods, in AppendixÂ E we compare ECUQ with three popular compression techniques that do not rely on quantization, namely, Rand-K, Top-KÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2018), and Count-SketchÂ (Charikar etÂ al., 2002) and show similar trends. Nevertheless, we note that quantization is mostly orthogonal to such techniques and they can be used in conjunction555For example, Vargaftik etÂ al. (2022) use Rand-K as a subroutine alongside quantization to reach a sub-bit compression ratio..

5 Experiments

As previously mentioned, most prior downlink compression methods rely on repeated client participation and/or control variates and are, therefore, less suitable for large-scale cross-device FL where a client may participate only once or a handful of times during the training procedure. Also, there are prior methods that target model size reduction via sketchingÂ (Rabbani etÂ al., 2021) and sparsificationÂ (Shah & Lau, 2021), but rely on restrictive assumptions and typically result in longer training times and lower accuracy with an increasing number of clients and decreasing participation ratio. Some other model size reduction methods, such as low-rank approximationÂ (e.g., Tai etÂ al. (2016)) are orthogonal to DoCoFL and they can be used in conjunction.

Accordingly, we compare DoCoFL with an uncompressed baseline obtained by running FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) without any (i.e., uplink or downlink) compression, utilizing full precision (i.e., 32-bit floats) in both directions. Then, we perform an ablation study that shows the consistency of DoCoFL with respect to its hyperparameters.

We cover a wide range of use cases that include two image classification and two language processing tasks with different configurations and data partitioning, as shortly summarized in TableÂ 2 and further detailed in AppendixÂ F.

Image Classification. We use the CIFAR-100 and EMNIST datasets. For CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), the data distribution among the clients is i.i.d. For EMNIST (Cohen etÂ al., 2017), the dataset of each client is composed of 10%percent1010\% i.i.d samples from the entire dataset and 90%percent9090\% i.i.d samples of 2 out of 47 classesÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020).

Language Processing. For language processing, we perform a sentiment analysis task on the Amazon Reviews datasetÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2015) with i.i.d data partitioning; and a next-character prediction task on the Shakespeare datasetÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), where each client holds data associated with a single role and play.

In all simulations, we run DoCoFL with ECUQ for anchor compression (i.e., ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w}), and EDENÂ (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2022) for correction and uplink compression (i.e., ğ’csubscriptğ’ğ‘\mathcal{C}_{c} and ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g}).

Main Results. In TableÂ 3, we report the best validation accuracy achieved during training for FedAvg and two representative configurations of DoCoFL. It is evident that the validation accuracy of DoCoFL and FedAvg is always competitive; in some tasks, DoCoFL performs somewhat better. For example, for EMNIST, DoCoFL reduces the online and total downlink bandwidth by 16Ã—16\times\! and 8Ã—8\times\!, respectively, while achieving higher validation accuracy.

As is often the case in FL, our evaluation indicates that using more bandwidth does not necessarily lead to higher validation accuracy. While using less bandwidth usually impacts the train accuracy, as it implies a larger compression error, it may positively affect the modelâ€™s generalization ability. We further reinforce these observations in AppendixÂ G.

Hyperparameters Ablation. In FigureÂ 3, we report the final train accuracy of DoCoFL for the CIFAR-100 task with varying values of Kâˆˆ{10,50,100,500}ğ¾1050100500K\in\{10,50,100,500\} and ğ’±âˆˆ{3,5,10}ğ’±3510{\mathcal{V}}\in\{3,5,10\} under two bandwidth configurations. The results indicate that our framework performs as expected for a wide range of anchor deployment rates and queue capacities. Additionally, in line with our theoretical findings, when the multiplication Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ¾ğ’±K{\mathcal{V}} is too large, the norm of the correction becomes sizable, which can hinder the final accuracy and even convergence. To allow the use of large Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ¾ğ’±K{\mathcal{V}}, one may increase the correction bandwidth, trading online bandwidth for a larger anchor download time window. We defer an ablation study of the anchor and correction bandwidth budgets to SectionÂ G.2. These results indicate that DoCoFL performs well for a wide range of budgets and provide further intuition for configuring these parameters.

The Value of the Correction Term. When ignoring the correction, DoCoFL may resemble other frameworks such as delayed gradients (e.g., Stich & Karimireddy (2019)) and asynchronous SGD (e.g., Lian etÂ al. (2015)). In SectionÂ G.3 we discuss this similarity and convey that ignoring the correction leads to a significant performance drop.

DoCoFL and EF21. In SectionÂ G.4, we focus on recent advancements based on the EF21 techniqueÂ (RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al., 2021), which relies on client-side memory. Specifically, we extend EF21-PPÂ (Fatkhullin etÂ al., 2021) to support downlink bandwidth reduction using DoCoFL while matching baseline accuracy, where naive model compression results in performance degradation. Also, we discuss some similarities with EF21-P + DIANAÂ (Gruntkowska etÂ al., 2022).

6 Conclusion

In this work, we presented DoCoFL, a framework for downlink compression in the challenging cross-device FL setup. By enlarging the clientsâ€™ model download time window, reducing total downlink bandwidth requirements, and allowing for uplink compression, DoCoFL is designed to allow more resource-constrained and diverse clients to participate in the training procedure. Experiments over various tasks indicate that DoCoFL indeed significantly reduces bi-directional bandwidth usage while performing competitively with an uncompressed baseline. In AppendixÂ H, we discuss some directions for future research.

Acknowledgements

We thank the reviewers and the area chair for their helpful suggestions. KYL is supported by the Israel Science Foundation (grant No.Â 447/20) and the Technion Center for Machine Learning and Intelligent Systems (MLIS).

Appendix A Suboptimality of Gradient Descent with Weights Compression

In this section, we give an example of a (strongly) convex function on â„â„{\mathbb{R}}, for which we show that running gradient descent with gradients computed at estimated (i.e., lossily compressed and then decompressed) iterates (rather than at the exact iterates) does not converge to the global minimum. Instead, it converges to a suboptimal solution.

Let f:â„â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’â„â„f:{\mathbb{R}}\to{\mathbb{R}} be the following convex and smooth function:

fâ€‹(w)=12â€‹(wâˆ’1)2+12â€‹[wâˆ’1]+2,ğ‘“ğ‘¤12superscriptğ‘¤1212superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘¤12f(w)=\frac{1}{2}(w-1)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left[w-1\right]_{+}^{2}\;,

where [w]+=maxâ¡(0,w)subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘¤0ğ‘¤\left[w\right]_{+}=\max\left(0,w\right). Note that wâˆ—=1superscriptğ‘¤1w^{*}=1 is the global minimizer of fğ‘“f. We analyze the following update rule:

wt+1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1\displaystyle w_{t+1} =wtâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(w^t)absentsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle=w_{t}-\eta\nabla f(\hat{w}_{t})
w^tsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle\hat{w}_{t} =ğ’wâ€‹(wt),absentsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathcal{C}_{w}(w_{t})\;,

where Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 is the step size, and ğ’:â„â†’â„:ğ’â†’â„â„\mathcal{C}:{\mathbb{R}}\to{\mathbb{R}} is a randomized, unbiased compression operator with bounded NMSE, i.e.,

ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’wâ€‹(w)]=w,ğ”¼â€‹|ğ’wâ€‹(w)âˆ’w|2â‰¤Ï‰w2â€‹|w|2,âˆ€wâˆˆâ„.formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘¤formulae-sequenceğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘¤2superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¤2superscriptğ‘¤2for-allğ‘¤â„\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{C}_{w}(w)]=w,\quad\mathbb{E}\lvert\mathcal{C}_{w}(w)-w\rvert^{2}\leq\omega_{w}^{2}\lvert w\rvert^{2},\quad\forall w\in{\mathbb{R}}\;.

We can alternatively write: w^t=wt+Ïµtâ€‹|wt|subscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\hat{w}_{t}=w_{t}+\epsilon_{t}\lvert w_{t}\rvert, where ğ”¼â€‹[Ïµt]=0,ğ”¼â€‹[Ïµt2]â‰¤Ï‰w2formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡0ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¤2\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{t}]=0,\,\,\mathbb{E}[\epsilon_{t}^{2}]\leq\omega_{w}^{2}, and {Ïµt}tsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡ğ‘¡\left\{\epsilon_{t}\right\}_{t} are independent. Thus, we can rewrite the above update rule as

wt+1=wtâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(wt+Ïµtâ€‹|wt|).subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\eta\nabla f(w_{t}+\epsilon_{t}\lvert w_{t}\rvert)\;. (9)

In Eq.Â (9), we repeatedly apply the stochastic mapping: wâ†¦wâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(w+Ïµâ€‹|w|)maps-toğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¤italic-Ïµğ‘¤w\mapsto w-\eta\nabla f(w+\epsilon\lvert w\rvert). If this process converges in expectation, it converges to a point w~~ğ‘¤\tilde{w} for which ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(w~+Ïµâ€‹|w~|)]=0ğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“~ğ‘¤italic-Ïµ~ğ‘¤0\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\tilde{w}+\epsilon\lvert\tilde{w}\rvert)]=0. We show that wâˆ—=1superscriptğ‘¤1w^{*}=1 does not satisfy this condition, which will imply that this process does not converge to wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}. First, note that fğ‘“f is differentiable, and âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)=(wâˆ’1)+[wâˆ’1]+âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¤ğ‘¤1subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘¤1\nabla f(w)=(w-1)+\left[w-1\right]_{+}. Thus,

ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(wâˆ—+Ïµâ€‹|wâˆ—|)]ğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¤italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘¤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla f(w^{*}+\epsilon\lvert w^{*}\rvert)\right] =ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(1+Ïµ)]=ğ”¼â€‹[Ïµ+[Ïµ]+]=ğ”¼â€‹[Ïµ]+,absentğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“1italic-Ïµğ”¼delimited-[]italic-Ïµsubscriptdelimited-[]italic-Ïµğ”¼subscriptdelimited-[]italic-Ïµ\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla f(1+\epsilon)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\epsilon+\left[\epsilon\right]_{+}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\epsilon\right]_{+}\;,

where the last equality follows from the linearity of expectation, ğ”¼â€‹[Ïµ]=0ğ”¼delimited-[]italic-Ïµ0\mathbb{E}[\epsilon]=0. Now, note that unless Ïµ=0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon=0 almost surely, we necessarily have ğ”¼â€‹[maxâ¡{0,Ïµ}]>0ğ”¼delimited-[]0italic-Ïµ0\mathbb{E}[\max\left\{0,\epsilon\right\}]>0, which implies that the iterative update in Eq.Â (9) does not converge in expectation to wâˆ—=1superscriptğ‘¤1w^{*}=1.

Appendix B Why DoCoFL with Anchor Compression Works

To support TheoremÂ 3.4, in which we establish the convergence of DoCoFL when the anchor compression ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is identity, in this section we give theoretical intuition and numerical results that convey as for why DoCoFL works when ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is not the identity mapping.

Consider the framework we analyze in AppendixÂ C, namely the generalization of DoCoFL given by AlgorithmÂ 3. Adding an anchor compressor (i.e., ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w}) implies that each client now obtains a compressed outdated model y^ti=ğ’wâ€‹(yti)superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{y}_{t}^{i}=\mathcal{C}_{w}(y_{t}^{i}) and a corresponding correction Î”^ti=ğ’câ€‹(wtâˆ’y^ti)superscriptsubscript^Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{\Delta}_{t}^{i}=\mathcal{C}_{c}(w_{t}-\hat{y}_{t}^{i}), and constructs w^ti=y^ti+Î”^tisuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{w}_{t}^{i}=\hat{y}_{t}^{i}+\hat{\Delta}_{t}^{i}. Thus, adding an anchor compression affects the clientâ€™s model estimation error ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}, which we bound in Eq.Â (23).

Denote by et,i2â‰”âˆ¥yti+Î”^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2â‰”superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2e_{t,i}^{2}\coloneqq\lVert y_{t}^{i}+\hat{\Delta}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2} the clientâ€™s squared estimation error when not using anchor compression (i.e., when ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} is identity), and by e^t,i2â‰”âˆ¥y^ti+Î”^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2â‰”superscriptsubscript^ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\hat{e}_{t,i}^{2}\coloneqq\lVert\hat{y}_{t}^{i}+\hat{\Delta}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2} the squared estimation error when using anchor compression. If one could show that the following condition holds:

ğ”¼â€‹[e^t,i2]â‰¤C2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[et,i2],ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript^ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2superscriptğ¶2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\mathbb{E}[\hat{e}_{t,i}^{2}]\leq C^{2}\mathbb{E}[e_{t,i}^{2}]\;, (10)

for some moderate C>0ğ¶0C>0, then we can simply bound ğ”¼â€‹[e^t,i2]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript^ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\mathbb{E}[\hat{e}_{t,i}^{2}] in the left-hand side of Eq.Â (23), and the rest of our analysis holds. However, we know that, in general, this condition does not hold (recall the counter-example in AppendixÂ A).

Nevertheless, we empirically show that it holds in our evaluation where we have non-convex and noisy optimization. More generally, in cross-device FL, client sampling and stochastic gradient estimation add natural noise to the optimization process, and we empirically show that the additional estimation error due to anchor compression with ECUQ is sufficiently low and allows convergence, as conveyed above.

In FigureÂ 4 we present the ratio Ïtâ‰”âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®te^t,i2/âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tet,i2â‰”subscriptğœŒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript^ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\rho_{t}\coloneqq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}{\hat{e}_{t,i}^{2}}/\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}{e_{t,i}^{2}} for different anchor compression budgets in CIFAR-100 and Amazon Reviews experiments. First, note that the ratio is mostly stable throughout the entire training. Additionally, when we increase the bandwidth for anchor compression, the ratio decreases, to the extent that for 888 bits per coordinate, the ratio is â‰ˆ1absent1\approx 1; this is when the error induced by the correction compression dominates the estimation error.

We note that our intuition gives rise to using an adaptive budget for anchor compression; since ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} can be measured by the PS (i.e., it has access to yti,y^tisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–y_{t}^{i},\hat{y}_{t}^{i}, wtsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{t} and the correction compressor ğ’csubscriptğ’ğ‘\mathcal{C}_{c}), we can keep track of it, and increase the anchor compression budget if ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} is too large. We leave such investigation to future work.

Appendix C Proof of TheoremÂ 3.4

In this section we prove TheoremÂ 3.4, which we restate here for convenience,

Theorem 3.4.

Let Ïƒ~2â‰”Ïƒ2+4â€‹(1âˆ’SN)â€‹G2,Î³â‰”1+(1âˆ’SN)â€‹B2Sformulae-sequenceâ‰”superscript~ğœ2superscriptğœ241ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğº2â‰”ğ›¾11ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğµ2ğ‘†\tilde{\sigma}^{2}\coloneqq\sigma^{2}+4\left(1-\frac{S}{N}\right)G^{2},\gamma\coloneqq 1+\left(1-\frac{S}{N}\right)\frac{B^{2}}{S}, and Mâ‰”fâ€‹(w0)âˆ’fâˆ—â‰”ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤0superscriptğ‘“M\coloneqq f(w_{0})-f^{*}. Then, running DoCoFL with ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} and ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g} as the identity mappings (and with appropriately selected Î·ğœ‚\eta) guarantees

ğ”¼â€‹[1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(wt)âˆ¥2]âˆˆğ’ªâ€‹(Mâ€‹Î²â€‹Ïƒ~2Tâ€‹S+(M2â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±â€‹Ïƒ~2)1/3T2/3â€‹S1/3+Î³â€‹Mâ€‹Î²â€‹(Ï‰â€‹Kâ€‹ğ’±+1)T).ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2ğ’ªğ‘€ğ›½superscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†superscriptsuperscriptğ‘€2superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2ğ¾ğ’±superscript~ğœ213superscriptğ‘‡23superscriptğ‘†13ğ›¾ğ‘€ğ›½ğœ”ğ¾ğ’±1ğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\lVert\nabla f(w_{t})\rVert^{2}}\right]\in\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{M\beta\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{TS}}+\frac{(M^{2}\beta^{2}\omega^{2}K{\mathcal{V}}\tilde{\sigma}^{2})^{1/3}}{T^{2/3}S^{1/3}}+\frac{\gamma M\beta(\omega K{\mathcal{V}}+1)}{T}\right).
Proof.

To simplify mathematical notations and computations, we analyze a more general framework than DoCoFL, where at each round, each client can download any model from up to ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} rounds prior to their participation round as anchor. This generalized policy is described in AlgorithmÂ 3.

Using 1, that proves the convergence of AlgorithmÂ 3 (see SectionÂ C.1), we prove TheoremÂ 3.4. Namely, DoCoFL with ğ’wsubscriptğ’ğ‘¤\mathcal{C}_{w} and ğ’gsubscriptğ’ğ‘”\mathcal{C}_{g} as identity mappings is a private case of AlgorithmÂ 3 where ğ’¯=Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ’¯ğ¾ğ’±\mathcal{T}=K{\mathcal{V}} and clients can only download models from specific prior rounds (multiplications of Kğ¾K). Thus, plugging-in ğ’¯=Kâ€‹ğ’±ğ’¯ğ¾ğ’±\mathcal{T}=K{\mathcal{V}} to 1 concludes the proof. âˆ

C.1 Proof of TheoremÂ 1

Theorem 1.

Suppose AssumptionsÂ 3.1-3.3 are satisfied. Let Ïƒ~2â‰”Ïƒ2+4â€‹(1âˆ’SN)â€‹G2,Î³â‰”1+(1âˆ’SN)â€‹B2S,Î¸â‰”Ï‰â€‹ğ’¯+1formulae-sequenceâ‰”superscript~ğœ2superscriptğœ241ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğº2formulae-sequenceâ‰”ğ›¾11ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğµ2ğ‘†â‰”ğœƒğœ”ğ’¯1\tilde{\sigma}^{2}\coloneqq\sigma^{2}+4\left(1-\frac{S}{N}\right)G^{2},\gamma\coloneqq 1+\left(1-\frac{S}{N}\right)\frac{B^{2}}{S},\theta\coloneqq\omega\mathcal{T}+1, and Mâ‰”fâ€‹(w0)âˆ’fâˆ—â‰”ğ‘€ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤0superscriptğ‘“M\coloneqq f(w_{0})-f^{*}. Then, running AlgorithmÂ 3 with Î·=minâ¡{130â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î¸,2â€‹Mâ€‹SÎ²â€‹Ïƒ~2â€‹T,(Mâ€‹S12â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹ğ’¯â€‹Ïƒ~2â€‹T)1/3}ğœ‚130ğ›¾ğ›½ğœƒ2ğ‘€ğ‘†ğ›½superscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘€ğ‘†12superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2ğ’¯superscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡13\eta=\min\left\{\frac{1}{30\gamma\beta\theta},\sqrt{\frac{2MS}{\beta\tilde{\sigma}^{2}T}},\left(\frac{MS}{12\beta^{2}\omega^{2}\mathcal{T}\tilde{\sigma}^{2}T}\right)^{1/3}\right\} guarantees

ğ”¼â€‹[1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(wt)âˆ¥2]â‰¤4â€‹2â€‹Mâ€‹Î²â€‹Ïƒ~2Tâ€‹S+8â€‹(12â€‹M2â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹ğ’¯â€‹Ïƒ~2)1/3T2/3â€‹S1/3+120â€‹Î³â€‹Mâ€‹Î²â€‹Î¸T.ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡242ğ‘€ğ›½superscript~ğœ2ğ‘‡ğ‘†8superscript12superscriptğ‘€2superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2ğ’¯superscript~ğœ213superscriptğ‘‡23superscriptğ‘†13120ğ›¾ğ‘€ğ›½ğœƒğ‘‡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\lVert\nabla f(w_{t})\rVert^{2}}\right]\leq 4\sqrt{\frac{2M\beta\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{TS}}+8\frac{(12M^{2}\beta^{2}\omega^{2}\mathcal{T}\tilde{\sigma}^{2})^{1/3}}{T^{2/3}S^{1/3}}+\frac{120\gamma M\beta\theta}{T}\;. (11)
Proof.

For the ease of notation, let âˆ‡tâ‰”âˆ‡fâ€‹(wt)â‰”subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\nabla_{t}\coloneqq\nabla f(w_{t}) and Ïƒ~S2â‰”Ïƒ~2/Sâ‰”subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†superscript~ğœ2ğ‘†\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}\coloneqq\tilde{\sigma}^{2}/S. Throughout our analysis, we sometimes use w^tisuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{w}_{t}^{i} even when iâˆ‰ğ’®tğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\notin\mathcal{S}_{t}, which is not well-defined. To resolve this, one can think about the following mathematically equivalent process, where at each round, all clients iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in\left[N\right] obtain some previous model (anchor) ytisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘–y_{t}^{i} and the corresponding correction Î”^tisuperscriptsubscript^Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{\Delta}_{t}^{i}, but only iâˆˆğ’®tğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\in\mathcal{S}_{t} actually participate in the optimization. In that sense, for all iâˆ‰ğ’®tğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\notin\mathcal{S}_{t}, w^tisuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{w}_{t}^{i} is the estimated model of client iğ‘–i if it were to participate in round tğ‘¡t.

Let âˆ‡^tâ‰”1Nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[N]âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w^ti)=ğ”¼â€‹[g^t]â‰”subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡\hat{\nabla}_{t}\coloneqq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in\left[N\right]}{\nabla f_{i}(\hat{w}_{t}^{i})}=\mathbb{E}[\hat{g}_{t}]. From the Î²ğ›½\beta-smoothness of the objective,

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})] â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[g^tâŠ¤â€‹âˆ‡t]+Î²â€‹Î·22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2absentğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leq-\eta\mathbb{E}[\hat{g}_{t}^{\top}\nabla_{t}]+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}
=âˆ’Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡^tâŠ¤â€‹âˆ‡t]+Î²â€‹Î·22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2absentğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=-\eta\mathbb{E}[\hat{\nabla}_{t}^{\top}\nabla_{t}]+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}
=âˆ’Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡tâŠ¤(âˆ‡tâˆ’âˆ‡^t)]âŸ=(A)+Î²â€‹Î·22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2,absentğœ‚ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2subscriptâŸğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡absentğ´ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=-\eta\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\underbrace{\eta\mathbb{E}[\nabla_{t}^{\top}(\nabla_{t}-\hat{\nabla}_{t})]}_{=(A)}+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}\;, (12)

where the first equality follows from the law of total expectation, and the second equality from the linearity of expectation.

Bounding (A)ğ´(A):

Using the inequality aâŠ¤â€‹bâ‰¤12â€‹âˆ¥aâˆ¥2+12â€‹âˆ¥bâˆ¥2superscriptğ‘topğ‘12superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘212superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘2a^{\top}b\leq\frac{1}{2}\lVert a\rVert^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\lVert b\rVert^{2}, we get that

Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡tâŠ¤(âˆ‡tâˆ’âˆ‡^t)]â‰¤Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ’âˆ‡^tâˆ¥2.ğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡2\eta\mathbb{E}[\nabla_{t}^{\top}(\nabla_{t}-\hat{\nabla}_{t})]\leq\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}-\hat{\nabla}_{t}\rVert^{2}\;.

Focusing on the second term in the right-hand side, we have:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ’âˆ‡^tâˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}-\hat{\nabla}_{t}\rVert^{2} =ğ”¼â€‹â€–1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1N(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(wt)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w^ti))â€–2absentğ”¼superscriptnorm1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left\|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\left(\nabla f_{i}(w_{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\hat{w}_{t}^{i})\right)}\right\|^{2}
â‰¤1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fiâ€‹(wt)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w^ti)âˆ¥2absent1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w_{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\hat{w}_{t}^{i})\rVert^{2}}
â‰¤Î²2Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2,absentsuperscriptğ›½2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\beta^{2}}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\;, (13)

where in the first inequality we used LemmaÂ C.5, and the second inequality follows from the Î²ğ›½\beta-smoothness of each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}. Plugging back this bound, we get:

Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡tâŠ¤(âˆ‡tâˆ’âˆ‡^t)]â‰¤Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²2â€‹Î·2â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2.ğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘¡ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\eta\mathbb{E}[\nabla_{t}^{\top}(\nabla_{t}-\hat{\nabla}_{t})]\leq\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\;.

Using LemmaÂ C.1 to bound ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥g^tâˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{g}_{t}\rVert^{2} and the bound on (A)ğ´(A), we get from Eq.Â (C.1) that

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})]\leq âˆ’Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²2â€‹Î·2â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2ğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle-\frac{\eta}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}
+Î²â€‹Î·22â€‹(Ïƒ~S2+4â€‹Î³â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+2â€‹Î²2Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2)ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†4ğ›¾ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡22superscriptğ›½2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}\left(\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}+4\gamma\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{2\beta^{2}}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\right)
=\displaystyle= (âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²â€‹Î·2â€‹Ïƒ~S22ğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†2\displaystyle\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}+2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}}{2}
+(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2)â‹…1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥2.â‹…superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚21ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\displaystyle+\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\cdot\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}}\;.

Applying LemmaÂ C.2, we can bound 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥w^tiâˆ’wtâˆ¥21ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{w}_{t}^{i}-w_{t}\rVert^{2}} to get that

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]â‰¤ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})]\leq (âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+Î²â€‹Î·2â€‹Ïƒ~S22ğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†2\displaystyle\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}+2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\beta\eta^{2}\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}}{2}
+(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2)â€‹[Î±â€‹(1+âˆ‘k=1tkâ€‹(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)k)â€‹Ïƒ~S2+2â€‹Î³Î²2â€‹ğ’¯â€‹âˆ‘k=1t(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)kâ€‹âˆ‘â„“=tâˆ’kâ€‹ğ’¯tâˆ’kğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2]superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚2delimited-[]ğ›¼1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğœğ‘†22ğ›¾superscriptğ›½2ğ’¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\displaystyle+\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\left[\alpha\left(1+\sum_{k=1}^{t}{k(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}\right)\tilde{\sigma}_{S}^{2}+\frac{2\gamma}{\beta^{2}\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k=1}^{t}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}\sum_{\ell=t-k\mathcal{T}}^{t-k}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}}\right]
=\displaystyle= (âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+[Î²â€‹Î·22+Î±â€‹(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2)â€‹(1+âˆ‘k=1tkâ€‹(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)k)]â€‹Ïƒ~S2ğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2delimited-[]ğ›½superscriptğœ‚22ğ›¼superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚21superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğœğ‘†2\displaystyle\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}+2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\left[\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}+\alpha\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\left(1+\sum_{k=1}^{t}{k(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}\right)\right]\tilde{\sigma}_{S}^{2}
+(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2)â€‹2â€‹Î³Î²2â€‹ğ’¯â€‹âˆ‘k=1t(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)kâ€‹âˆ‘â„“=tâˆ’kâ€‹ğ’¯tâˆ’kğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2âŸ=(B),superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚22ğ›¾superscriptğ›½2ğ’¯subscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2absentğµ\displaystyle+\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\frac{2\gamma}{\beta^{2}\mathcal{T}}\underbrace{\sum_{k=1}^{t}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}\sum_{\ell=t-k\mathcal{T}}^{t-k}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}}}_{=(B)}\;, (14)

where Î±=4â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹ğ’¯ğ›¼4superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2ğ’¯\alpha=4\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\mathcal{T} and Ï=20â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î·2â€‹ğ’¯ğœŒ20superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2superscriptğœ‚2ğ’¯\rho=20\beta^{2}\omega^{2}\eta^{2}\mathcal{T}. Since Î·â‰¤130â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹(Ï‰â€‹ğ’¯+1)â‰¤140â€‹Î²â€‹Ï‰â€‹ğ’¯ğœ‚130ğ›¾ğ›½ğœ”ğ’¯1140ğ›½ğœ”ğ’¯\eta\leq\frac{1}{30\gamma\beta(\omega\mathcal{T}+1)}\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{40}\beta\omega\mathcal{T}}, it holds that Ïâ€‹ğ’¯=20â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹ğ’¯2â€‹Î·2â‰¤1/2<1ğœŒğ’¯20superscriptğ›½2superscriptğœ”2superscriptğ’¯2superscriptğœ‚2121\rho\mathcal{T}=20\beta^{2}\omega^{2}\mathcal{T}^{2}\eta^{2}\leq 1/2<1, and thus we can bound the coefficient of Ïƒ~S2superscriptsubscript~ğœğ‘†2\tilde{\sigma}_{S}^{2} using LemmaÂ C.7 as

âˆ‘k=1tkâ€‹(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)kâ‰¤âˆ‘k=1âˆkâ€‹(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)k=Ïâ€‹ğ’¯(1âˆ’Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)2â‰¤4â€‹Ïâ€‹ğ’¯â‰¤2,superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘˜superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜ğœŒğ’¯superscript1ğœŒğ’¯24ğœŒğ’¯2\sum_{k=1}^{t}{k(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}\leq\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}{k(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}=\frac{\rho\mathcal{T}}{(1-\rho\mathcal{T})^{2}}\leq 4\rho\mathcal{T}\leq 2\;, (15)

where we used 1(1âˆ’Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)2â‰¤41superscript1ğœŒğ’¯24\frac{1}{(1-\rho\mathcal{T})^{2}}\leq 4, and Ïâ€‹ğ’¯â‰¤1/2ğœŒğ’¯12\rho\mathcal{T}\leq 1/2.

Bounding (B)ğµ(B):

To bound (B)ğµ(B), we change the summation order. Consider a fixed â„“âˆˆâ„•â„“â„•\ell\in{\mathbb{N}}. Note that (Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)ksuperscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k} appears as a coefficient of ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2} if and only if tâˆ’kâ€‹ğ’¯â‰¤â„“â‰¤tâˆ’kğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ’¯â„“ğ‘¡ğ‘˜t-k\mathcal{T}\leq\ell\leq t-k, which is equivalent to tâˆ’â„“ğ’¯â‰¤kâ‰¤tâˆ’â„“ğ‘¡â„“ğ’¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„“\frac{t-\ell}{\mathcal{T}}\leq k\leq t-\ell. Therefore, we have

âˆ‘k=1t(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)kâ€‹âˆ‘â„“=tâˆ’kâ€‹ğ’¯tâˆ’kğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¡superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{t}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}\sum_{\ell=t-k\mathcal{T}}^{t-k}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}} =âˆ‘â„“=0tâˆ’1(âˆ‘k=âŒˆtâˆ’â„“ğ’¯âŒ‰tâˆ’â„“(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)k)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2absentsuperscriptsubscriptâ„“0ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„“ğ’¯ğ‘¡â„“superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\displaystyle=\sum_{\ell=0}^{t-1}{\left(\sum_{k=\lceil\frac{t-\ell}{\mathcal{T}}\rceil}^{t-\ell}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}
â‰¤âˆ‘â„“=0tâˆ’1(âˆ‘k=âŒˆtâˆ’â„“ğ’¯âŒ‰âˆ(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)k)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2absentsuperscriptsubscriptâ„“0ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„“ğ’¯superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘˜ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\displaystyle\leq\sum_{\ell=0}^{t-1}{\left(\sum_{k=\lceil\frac{t-\ell}{\mathcal{T}}\rceil}^{\infty}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{k}}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}
=11âˆ’Ïâ€‹ğ’¯â€‹âˆ‘â„“=0tâˆ’1(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)âŒˆtâˆ’â„“ğ’¯âŒ‰â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡â„“âˆ¥2absent11ğœŒğ’¯superscriptsubscriptâ„“0ğ‘¡1superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘¡â„“ğ’¯ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡â„“2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{1-\rho\mathcal{T}}\sum_{\ell=0}^{t-1}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{\lceil\frac{t-\ell}{\mathcal{T}}\rceil}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{\ell}\rVert^{2}}

Plugging this bound and Eq.Â (15) back to Eq.Â (C.1) gives

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})] â‰¤(âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+(Î²â€‹Î·22+3â€‹Î±â€‹(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2))â€‹Ïƒ~S2absentğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚223ğ›¼superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚2subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†\displaystyle\leq\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}+2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}+\left(\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}+3\alpha\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\right)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}
+(Î·+2â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹Î³(1âˆ’Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)â€‹ğ’¯â€‹âˆ‘k=0tâˆ’1(Ïâ€‹ğ’¯)âŒˆtâˆ’kğ’¯âŒ‰â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡kâˆ¥2.ğœ‚2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2ğ›¾1ğœŒğ’¯ğ’¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘¡1superscriptğœŒğ’¯ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ’¯ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+\left(\eta+2\beta\eta^{2}\right)\frac{\gamma}{(1-\rho\mathcal{T})\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k=0}^{t-1}{(\rho\mathcal{T})^{\lceil\frac{t-k}{\mathcal{T}}\rceil}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{k}\rVert^{2}}\;.

Summing over t=0,â€¦,Tâˆ’1ğ‘¡0â€¦ğ‘‡1t=0,\ldots,T-1, we obtain

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wT)âˆ’fâ€‹(w0)]=ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤0absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(w_{T})-f(w_{0})]= âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(wt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(wt)]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}[f(w_{t+1})-f(w_{t})]}
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq (âˆ’Î·2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î²â€‹Î·2)â€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡tâˆ¥2+(Î²â€‹Î·22+3â€‹Î±â€‹(Î²2â€‹Î·2+Î²3â€‹Î·2))â€‹Tâ€‹Ïƒ~S2ğœ‚22ğ›¾ğ›½superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¡2ğ›½superscriptğœ‚223ğ›¼superscriptğ›½2ğœ‚2superscriptğ›½3superscriptğœ‚2ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscript~ğœ2ğ‘†\displaystyle\left(-\frac{\eta}{2}+2\gamma\beta\eta^{2}\right)\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla_{t}\rVert^{2}}+\left(\frac{\beta\eta^{2}}{2}+3\alpha\left(\frac{\beta^{2}\eta}{2}+\beta^{3}\eta^{2}\right)\right)T\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{S}
